section.title: Phase Plane Analysis of Linear Systems

subsection.title: The Case \lambda_1 \lt 0 \lt \lambda_2

example.p:
The system
x' \amp = x + 3y y' \amp = x - y
can be written in matrix form \mathbf x' = A \mathbf x, where A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}. The eigenvalues of A are \lambda = -2 or \lambda = 2 with eigenvectors \mathbf u = (1, -1) and \mathbf v = (3,1), respectively. Therefore, the straightline solutions must be lines containing \mathbf u and \mathbf v ().

image.sageplot: x, y ,t = var('x y t') F = [x + 3*y, x - y] n = sqrt(F[0]^2 + F[1]^2) p = plot_vector_field((F[0]/n, F[1]/n), (x,-3,3), (y,-3,3), aspect_ratio=1, axes_labels=['$x(t)$','$y(t)$'], fontsize=12) p += line([(-3,-1), (3,1)], thickness = 2) p += line([(-3,3), (3,-3)], thickness = 2) p += arrow((0,0), (1,-1), color="red", arrowsize=3, width = 4) p += arrow((0,0), (3,1), color="red", arrowsize=3, width = 4) p

subsection.p:
Let us consider the special case of the system {\mathbf x}' = A {\mathbf x}, where \lambda_1 \lt 0 \lt \lambda_2 and A = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda_1 & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda_2 \end{pmatrix}. Since this is a decoupled system,
\frac{dx}{dt} & = \lambda_1 x \frac{dy}{dt} & = \lambda_2 y,
we already know how to find the solutions. However, in keeping with the spirit of our investigation, we will find the eigenvalues of A. The characteristic equation of A is (\lambda - \lambda_1)(\lambda - \lambda_2) = 0, and our eigenvalues are \lambda_1 and \lambda_2. It is easy to see that we can associate eigenvectors (1,0) and (0, 1) to \lambda_1 and \lambda_2, respectively. Thus, our general solution is {\mathbf x}(t) = c_1 e^{\lambda_1 t} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} + c_2 e^{\lambda_2 t} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.

image.sageplot: x, y ,t = var('x y t') F = [-x, y] n = sqrt(F[0]^2 + F[1]^2) v = plot_vector_field((F[0]/n, F[1]/n), (x,-3,3), (y,-3,3), aspect_ratio=1) P1=desolve_system_rk4(F,[x,y],ics=[0,-3,0.1],ivar=t,end_points=3.4,step=0.1) P2=desolve_system_rk4(F,[x,y],ics=[0,-3,-0.1],ivar=t,end_points=3.4,step=0.1) P3=desolve_system_rk4(F,[x,y],ics=[0,3,0.1],ivar=t,end_points=3.4,step=0.1) P4=desolve_system_rk4(F,[x,y],ics=[0,3,-0.1],ivar=t,end_points=3.4,step=0.1) S1=[ [j, k] for i,j,k in P1] S2=[ [j, k] for i,j,k in P2] S3=[ [j, k] for i,j,k in P3] S4=[ [j, k] for i,j,k in P4] LP1=line(S1, thickness=2, axes_labels=['$x(t)$','$y(t)$'], fontsize=12) LP2=line(S2, thickness=2) LP3=line(S3, thickness=2) LP4=line(S4, thickness=2) LP1 + LP2 + LP3 + LP4 + v

subsection.p:
Since \lambda_1 \lt 0, the straight-line solutions of the form c_1 e^{\lambda_1 t} (1, 0) lie on the x-axis. These solutions approach zero as t \to \infty. On the other hand, the solutions c_2 e^{\lambda_2 t} (0, 1) line on the y-axis and approach infinity as t \to \infty. The x-axis is called the stable line, and the y-axis is called the unstable line. All other solutions {\mathbf x}(t) = c_1 e^{\lambda_1 t} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} + c_2 e^{\lambda_2 t} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} (with c_1, c_2 \neq 0) tend to infinity in the direction of the unstable line, since {\mathbf x}(t) approaches (0, c_2 e^{\lambda_2 t} ) as t \to \infty. The phase portrait for the system
x' & = -x y' & = y
is given in . The equilibrium point of such systems is called a saddle.

image.sageplot: x, y ,t = var('x y t') F = [x + 3*y, x - y] n = sqrt(F[0]^2 + F[1]^2) v = plot_vector_field((F[0]/n, F[1]/n), (x,-3,3), (y,-3,3), aspect_ratio=1) P1=desolve_system_rk4(F,[x,y],ics=[0,-3,2.9],ivar=t,end_points=1.86,step=0.1) P2=desolve_system_rk4(F,[x,y],ics=[0,-2.9,3],ivar=t,end_points=1.86,step=0.1) P3=desolve_system_rk4(F,[x,y],ics=[0,3,-2.9],ivar=t,end_points=1.86,step=0.1) P4=desolve_system_rk4(F,[x,y],ics=[0,2.9,-3],ivar=t,end_points=1.86,step=0.1) S1=[ [j, k] for i,j,k in P1] S2=[ [j, k] for i,j,k in P2] S3=[ [j, k] for i,j,k in P3] S4=[ [j, k] for i,j,k in P4] LP1=line(S1, thickness=2, axes_labels=['$x(t)$','$y(t)$'], fontsize=12) LP2=line(S2, thickness=2) LP3=line(S3, thickness=2) LP4=line(S4, thickness=2) L1 = line([(-3,-1), (3,1)], thickness = 2, color="red") L2 = line([(-3,3), (3,-3)], thickness = 2, color="red") LP1 + LP2 + LP3 + LP4 + v + L1 + L2

subsection.p: For the general case, where A has eigenvalues \lambda_1 \lt 0 \lt \lambda_2, we always have a stable line of solutions and an unstable line of solutions. All other solutions approach the unstable line as t \to \infty and the stable line as t \to - \infty.

subsection.title: The Case \lambda_1 \lt \lambda_2 \lt 0

image.sageplot: x, y ,t = var('x y t') F = [-2*x, -y] n = sqrt(F[0]^2 + F[1]^2) v = plot_vector_field((F[0]/n, F[1]/n), (x,-3,3), (y,-3,3), aspect_ratio=1) P1=desolve_system_rk4(F,[x,y],ics=[0,-3,2.7],ivar=t,end_points=5,step=0.1) P2=desolve_system_rk4(F,[x,y],ics=[0,-3,-2.7],ivar=t,end_points=5,step=0.1) P3=desolve_system_rk4(F,[x,y],ics=[0,3,2.7],ivar=t,end_points=5,step=0.1) P4=desolve_system_rk4(F,[x,y],ics=[0,3,-2.7],ivar=t,end_points=5,step=0.1) S1=[ [j, k] for i,j,k in P1] S2=[ [j, k] for i,j,k in P2] S3=[ [j, k] for i,j,k in P3] S4=[ [j, k] for i,j,k in P4] LP1=line(S1, thickness=2, axes_labels=['$x(t)$','$y(t)$'], fontsize=12) LP2=line(S2, thickness=2) LP3=line(S3, thickness=2) LP4=line(S4, thickness=2) LP1 + LP2 + LP3 + LP4 + v

subsection.p: Since \lambda_1 \lt \lambda_2 \lt 0, we say that \lambda_1 is the dominant eigenvalue. The x-coordinates of the solutions approach the origin much faster than the y-coordinates.

To see what happens in the general case, suppose that \lambda_1 \lt \lambda_2 \lt 0, the eigenvectors associated with \lambda_1 and \lambda_2 are (u_1, u_2) and (v_1, v_2), respectively. The general solution of our system is {\mathbf x}(t) = c_1 e^{\lambda_1 t} \begin{pmatrix} u_1 \\ u_2 \end{pmatrix} + c_2 e^{\lambda_2 t} \begin{pmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{pmatrix}. The slope of a solution curve at (x, y) is given by
\frac{dy}{dx} & = \frac{\lambda_1 c_1 e^{\lambda_1 t} u_2 + \lambda_2 c_2 e^{\lambda_2 t} v_2} {\lambda_1 c_1 e^{\lambda_1 t} u_1 + \lambda_2 c_2 e^{\lambda_2 t} v_1} & = \left( \frac{\lambda_1 c_1 e^{\lambda_1 t} u_2 + \lambda_2 c_2 e^{\lambda_2 t} v_2} {\lambda_1 c_1 e^{\lambda_1 t} u_1 + \lambda_2 c_2 e^{\lambda_2 t} v_1} \right) \frac{e^{-\lambda_2 t}}{e^{-\lambda_2 t}} & = \frac{\lambda_1 c_1 e^{(\lambda_1 - \lambda_2) t} u_2 + \lambda_2 c_2 v_2} {\lambda_1 c_1 e^{(\lambda_1 - \lambda_2) t} u_1 + \lambda_2 c_2 v_1}.
This last expression tends toward the slope v_2/v_1 of the eigenvector of \lambda_2 (unless c_2 = 0). If c_2 = 0, then we have the straight-line solution corresponding to the eigenvalue \lambda_1. Hence, all the solutions for this case (except those on the straight-line belonging to the dominant eigenvalue) tend toward the origin tangentially to the straight-line solution corresponding to the weaker eigenvalue, \lambda_2.

subsection.title: The Case \lambda_1 \gt \lambda_2 \gt 0
subsection.p: If \lambda_1 \gt \lambda_2 \gt 0, we can regard our direction field as the negative of the direction field of the previous case. The general solution and the direction field are the same, but the arrows are reversed (). In this case, we say that the equilibrium point is a source.

image.sageplot: x, y ,t = var('x y t') F = [2*x, y] n = sqrt(F[0]^2 + F[1]^2) v = plot_vector_field((F[0]/n, F[1]/n), (x,-3,3), (y,-3,3), aspect_ratio=1) P1=desolve_system_rk4(F,[x,y],ics=[0,0.01,0.1],ivar=t,end_points=2.9,step=0.1) P2=desolve_system_rk4(F,[x,y],ics=[0,-0.01,0.1],ivar=t,end_points=2.9,step=0.1) P3=desolve_system_rk4(F,[x,y],ics=[0,0.01,-0.1],ivar=t,end_points=2.9,step=0.1) P4=desolve_system_rk4(F,[x,y],ics=[0,-0.01,-0.1],ivar=t,end_points=2.9,step=0.1) S1=[ [j, k] for i,j,k in P1] S2=[ [j, k] for i,j,k in P2] S3=[ [j, k] for i,j,k in P3] S4=[ [j, k] for i,j,k in P4] LP1=line(S1, thickness=2, axes_labels=['$x(t)$','$y(t)$'], fontsize=12) LP2=line(S2, thickness=2) LP3=line(S3, thickness=2) LP4=line(S4, thickness=2) LP1 + LP2 + LP3 + LP4 + v

li.p:
If A = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda_1 & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda_2 \end{pmatrix}, then A has two distinct real eigenvalues. The general solution to the system {\mathbf x}' = A {\mathbf x} is {\mathbf x}(t) = \alpha e^{\lambda_1 t} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} + \beta e^{\lambda_2 t} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.
For the case \lambda_1 \lt 0 \lt \lambda_2, the equilibrium point of the system {\mathbf x}' = A {\mathbf x} is a saddle.
For the case \lambda_1 \lt \lambda_2 \lt 0, the equilibrium point of the system {\mathbf x}' = A {\mathbf x} is a sink.
For the case 0 \lt \lambda_1 \lt \lambda_2, the equilibrium point of the system {\mathbf x}' = A {\mathbf x} is a source.

statement.p: Determine a computable condition that guarantees that, if a 2 \times 2 matrix A has complex eigenvalues, then the solutions of {\mathbf x}' = A{\mathbf x} travel around the origin in a counterclockwise direction.
